Rewind 2023: Climate Change Disasters have continued this year as capitalism has continued to let the planet burn, and thousands of people die from the impact of climate change, particularly in the Global South. Meanwhile, the talking shop for the rich jet-setting elite COP28 was held in one of the worst polluters in the world, the United Arab Emirates.

Europe recorded its highest-ever April temperatures during a heatwave as temperatures hit 38C in Spain. In May, 463 people were killed by Storm Mocha in Myanmar, while hundreds of people were killed in floods in the Democratic Republic of Congo, Rwanda, and Uganda. During the spring, 16 people were killed in the Turkish provinces of Adiyaman and Sanliurfa in flash floods that turned streets into rivers a month after the region experienced a devastating earthquake.
 
The year began with Storm Mara in the US, a deadly ice storm that hit Texas, Arkansas, and Tennessee from January 31 to February 2, killing 10 people and leading to 500,000 power outages. Similarly, Cyclone Freddy devastated Africa for five weeks in February and March, having formed over the Indian Ocean. It made landfall in Madagascar and Mozambique, killing at least 238 people. 
 
During the summer, the Mediteran region was engulfed in forest fires during another record heatwave. Greece was the country that suffered the most, with 80 wildfires that killed 28 people and injured 75 as temperatures reached 45 C. Deadly fires in Hawaii in August killed 106 people.
 
Flash floods hit Greece, Bulgaria, and Türkiye in early September. In Greece, there were at least 17 deaths and damage of €2.5 billion, while a state of emergency was declared in Bulgaria, and 12 people were swept away in Türkiye. Over 300 people have also been killed in floods in East Africa, displacing over 1 million people in Somalia, Kenya, Ethiopia, and Tanzania.

Two years ago today American author, feminist, educator, theorist, and social critic Gloria Jean Watkins better known by her pen name Bell Hooks died at the age of 69.  Hook's writing focused on the intersectionality of race, capitalism and gender and the way that they perpetuate class domination and oppression. She published around 40 books including essays, poems, and children's books while also giving numerous public lectures and appearing in documentaries. Her writing also addressed a wide range of other topics such as love, art, history, and the mass media.

Born to a working-class African American family in the segregated Kentucky town of Hopkinsville in September 1952, she was educated in racially segregated public schools before moving to an integrated school in the late 1960s which influenced her own perspective as an educator. An avid reader, Hooks gained a BA in English from Stanford University in 1973 followed by an MA in English from the University of Wisconsin in 1976 and a doctorate in English from the University of California Santa Cruz in 1983.

 Hooks began her academic career in 1976 teaching English and ethnic studies at the University of Southern California and went on to teach at Stanford, Yale, New College of Florida, The City College of New York, and Berea College in Kentucky. Her work was influenced by abolitionist and feminist Sojourner Truth, Brazilian educator Paulo Freire Peruvian theologian Gustavo Gutiérrez, Buddhist monk Thích Nhất Hạnh, and African-American writer James Baldwin. 

In Ain't I a Woman (1981) Hooks discussed the historical impact of racism and sexism on Black women and the idea of a white- supremacist -capitalist patriarchy that marginalizes Black women. In Feminist Theory: From Margin to Center(1984) she was critical of white feminist racism in second-wave feminism which undermined feminist solidarity across racial lines. She also became a prominent leftist and postmodern thinker.

Today is the 42nd anniversary of the start of one of the worst massacres in modern Latin American history, the El Mozote massacre perpetrated by US-trained forces in El Salvador. From December 11 to December 13 1981 a right-wing death squad slaughtered almost the entire population of the village of El Mozote. Over 1,000 people mostly women, children, and elderly people were brutally murdered. 

Girls as young as 10 were raped while children were murdered by having their throats slit and being hung from trees. After slaughtering almost the entire population, the death squad burnt the houses in the village. 

During the early 1980s, El Salvador was convulsed by a civil war between left-wing guerrillas known as the Farabundo Martí National Liberation Front (FMLN) and a pro-American military dictatorship. The population of El Mozote were considered FMLN sympathizers and the village became a haunting symbol of the US support for brutal massacres against left-wing movements across Latin America. It has been 1 year since the coup against Pedro Castillo in Peru. The US-backed dictatorship that replaced him launched numerous massacres against Indigenous protesters who were calling for the return of democracy. 

Throughout 2022, right-wing pro-Fujimori parties in congress were preparing to launch a legislative coup against President Castillo. In order to prevent this, on December 7th that year, Castillo announced new congressional elections and thereby suspending the existing congress until the new one was elected.  

In response, congress voted to impeach Castillo in an illegal session. The police and military, institutions shaped by the Fujimori dictatorship, sided with congress over the President and proceeded to arrest Pedro Castillo. This cleared the way for congress to install Dina Boluarte as President without a general election.  

Immediately, social movements, primarily in rural indigenous regions, began protesting against the coup. These protests escalated into a general strike in which most of the key highways across the country were blocked by protesters erecting barricades.  

In response, the new Boluarte regime declared a state of emergency and gave the police and military the green light to use live ammunition to clear roads and break up the protests. This is when the massacres across Quechua and Aymara regions began.

We are devastated at the news that Benjamin Zephaniah has passed away. Zephaniah was a revolutionary poet, actor, musician, writer and activist who touched the lives of millions. His work, especially his poems, reflected his lifelong struggle against racism and imperialism.

He was born in Birmingham in 1956 to a Barbadian father and a Jamaican mother, both Christians, and struggled with dyslexia as a child leaving school at the age of 13 unable to read or write. Zephaniah would become an iconic testament to the fact that formal education is not the only route towards creative and intellectual achievement, largely self-taught, he developed an early love of literature.

Zephaniah embraced Rastafarianism in his late teens and moved to London in the late 1970s. During the riots of the early 1980s, Zephaniah faced brutal racism from the far-right and the police. After being involved in a worker's co-op in East London, he established himself as a poet attacking the British legal system, reflecting on his travels in occupied Palestine and celebrating cultural diversity in Britain. Zephaniah also released musical tributes to Bob Marley and Nelson Mandela as well as appearing in various British TV programs including the worldwide hit Peaky Blinders which was set in his home city.

Benjamin Zephaniah was a fixture in the Palestine solidarity movement and a patron of Britain's Palestine Solidarity Campaign, which much of his activism was dedicated to. He was also a committed vegan and supported animal rights, an anarchist he endorsed socialist Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn and campaigned for a British republic. In 2003 he declined The Order of the British Empire (OBE) in protest against British imperialism and the Transatlantic Slave Trade.

Today, we commemorate Frantz Fanon, the Afro-Caribbean anti-colonial revolutionary who passed away in 1961. When he died at the young age of 36, his words had already inspired liberation movements worldwide. 
 
Fanon was born 98 years ago in the former French colony of Martinique, part of the West Indies. Later, as a psychiatrist, Fanon analyzed the sociopathological structure of the colonial system and worked closely with the Algerian National Liberation Front, which fought against French colonial rule.
 
His flagship work, "The Wretched of the Earth," became a classic of anti-colonial literature, with a print run in the millions. In chapter one, Fanon wrote, "Colonialism is not a thinking machine, nor a body endowed with reasoning faculties. It is violence in its natural state and will only yield when confronted with greater violence." 
 
The revolutionary Fanon died of leukemia in December 1961. More than half a century after Fanon's death, his writings are still vivid today.

Twelve years ago today, revolutionary Brazilian footballer Brasileiro Sampaio de Oliveira Sócrates, known as "Doctor Sócrates" or simply Sócrates, died in São Paulo. Sócrates used his fame and influence to fight for the rights of oppressed people. He was also a Brazilian Workers' Party member and saw Fidel Castro, Che Guevara, and John Lennon as his idols. While playing for the São Paulo club Corinthians, he co-founded the Corinthians Democracy movement, which challenged the capitalist model of running football clubs and the brutal military dictatorship in Brazil. Sócrates also supported the Diretas Já (Free elections now) movement in 1984, calling for direct presidential elections shortly before his move to Fiorentina in Italy. 
 
The Corinthians Democracy movement, founded in 1982, was an attempt to challenge the traditionally hierarchical structure of football clubs. It aimed to create a democratic, self-managed model where fans and players had a say in running their club. Under this model, the vote of a team's manager had the same weight as an ordinary fan about every single decision made at the club.
 
The Diretas Já movement, along with massive protests by students, workers, and artists, played a crucial role in ending the US-backed dictatorship that had ruled Brazil since 1964. It brutally repressed the left, committing heinous crimes such as detention without trial, torture, and hundreds of killings. 
 
Sócrates was a creative midfielder who could play in an attacking role or central midfield, who captained a skilful Brazil team at the 1982 World Cup Final in Spain. As well as being a Marxist, Sócrates was passionate about philosophy, art, and medicine, earning a medical degree at 24.

Today, we remember the late Fred Hampton, a legendary figure in the Black Panther Party and a revolutionary Marxist-Leninist, who was assassinated by the FBI on this day in 1969. Born in Chicago in 1948, Hampton served as the Black Panther Party's deputy chairman and the Illinois chapter's chair. His contributions as a prominent anti-racist figure and his commitment to multicultural organizing left a lasting impact.
 
Fred Hampton was instrumental in fostering alliances between various racial and ethnic groups. He was crucial in establishing the Young Patriots to organize poor whites and the Young Lords to organize Hispanics. Additionally, Hampton worked towards uniting Chicago street gangs to end internal conflicts and promote collaboration for social change.
 
Recognizing fascism as a significant threat to humanity, Hampton emphasized the critical importance of preventing its rise, believing that its impact would extend to everyone. Identified as a threat by the FBI, Hampton faced attempts to undermine his influence through the placement of spies within the Black Panthers. Tragically, in December 1969, he was murdered in cold blood by police who were assisting the FBI during a pre-dawn raid as 100 gunshots were fired into his apartment.
 
Watch Fred Hampton articulate how those in power exploit racism in capitalist societies to maintain control by dividing the working class and oppressed people. His insightful message remains relevant, particularly during increasing inequality and the resurgence of far-right movements.

68 years ago today Rosa Parks was arrested after refusing to give up her seat to a white passenger on a bus in the southern US state of Alabama. Yemen was officially declared an independent country on this day 56 years ago.

Yemen's independence day was the conclusion to 4 years of armed struggle led primarily by the leftist National Liberation Front and the Arab nationalist Front for the Liberation of Occupied South Yemen. 

From 1963 to 1967 the NLF led an arduous two-pronged struggle against both British colonial forces as well as the feudal sheikhdoms and sultanates in power all across what was then the Federation of South Arabia, a British colonial protectorate.

Throughout November 1967, the British colonial forces gradually evacuated Aden and Southern Yemen, as NLF forces drew closer. Mutinies in the puppet "South Arabia Army" were rampant and frequent, and on the 29th of November 1967, the final agreement for independence was signed in Geneva. The independence agreement took effect the forthcoming day.

The UN Climate Change Conference, or COP, is meeting today in Dubai to discuss climate change. Here are some facts they will likely ignore. Contrary to the usual narrative, the global north is the biggest polluter, responsible for 92% of excess CO2 emissions since 1750. The US has been responsible for a staggering 25% of historical emissions since 1750, while the Global South, effectively half the world, has only been responsible for 8%.

Transport workers in São Paulo, Brazil, paralyzed the city yesterday as they went on strike against the right-wing governor’s plan to privatize public transport. 

The São Paulo Metro & Rail Workers’ Union led the walkout despite the threat of prosecution after local courts said that metro workers were obliged to continue working, a ruling denounced as ‘authoritarian’ by union leader Camila Lisboa. 

Governor Tarcisio de Freitas, former Minister for Infrastructure under Jair Bolsonaro, is pushing the privatization plans. He has already privatized other essential services such as electricity and water. As a Minister, he pushed through a similar plan, privatizing 12 ports and 13 airports. 

Unions say that his privatization of electricity has been a disaster and led to city-wide blackouts due to the mass layoffs enforced by the private company Enel, which recently took over the service.

Freitas sees himself as a possible heir to Bolsonaro and the far-right politics he represented. He’s hoping to use his position as governor to launch himself for a possible election run, though mass protests and strikes could jeopardize that.

Happy 203rd birthday to Friedrich Engels, co-founder of scientific socialism and the international workers' movement! Over 100 years of class struggle are built on Engels' works and legacy.

Born into a bourgeois family, he committed class treason by working with his closest comrade Karl Marx to build the scientific foundation for a revolution that would put the worker at the top of the ruling order. Engels' legacy is not only composed of his work at his desk but also as a trained soldier who participated in numerous armed workers' uprisings and survived several battles.

After the death of Marx in 1883, Engels completed the last two volumes of the flagship work "Das Kapital." At the funeral, Engels said of Marx, "His name will live on through the centuries, and so will his work!" A few years after Engels' death, his and Marx's writings became the blueprint for the communist revolution in Russia that would change the world forever.

Protests against a French-Chinese led project to build the longest heated oil pipeline in the world have continued in Uganda and Tanzania this week. 

The construction of the $5 billion East African Crude Oil Pipeline (EACOP) is causing massive environmental destruction and displacing thousands of families along the 1,443 km route from Uganda's border with the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) to Tanzania. 

The mega-project is spearheaded by France's TotalEnergies and the Chinese state owned company CNOOC. 

The "Stop EACOP" campaign says the pipeline "threatens one of the most ecologically diverse and wildlife-rich regions of the world" and that it "would run through numerous important habitats and nature reserves – home to a number of iconic and endangered animals".

The pipeline will also run through Lake Victoria, Africa's largest lake, which millions rely on for water and farming. A leak could destroy this vital water resource. 

Campaigners estimate that EACOP will displace 100,000 people. Thousands have already being kicked off their land with insufficient compensation from the projects' backers.

Anti-EACOP protests mostly been held at Chinese embassies in Uganda, Tanzania, and the DRC.

Today we remember the revolutionary Mirabal sisters, also known as Las Mariposas, who fought against the deadly dictatorship of Rafael Trujillo in the Dominican Republic which led to the deaths of thousands. 

The eldest sister, Patria, was a mother of three and a political activist who once said, “We cannot allow our children to grow up in this corrupt and tyrannical regime. We have to fight against it, and I am willing to give up everything, even my life if necessary.”

Minerva, the sister who was the most vocal about the dictatorship, was arrested several times for fighting against the Trujillo regime and had her license to practice law revoked by Trujillo after reportedly rejecting his sexual advances. 

The youngest sister, María Teresa, was greatly inspired by her older sisters’ activism and joined the resistance. "Perhaps what we have most near is death, but that idea does not frighten me. We shall continue to fight for that which is just."

The sisters were violently assassinated by Trujillo’s henchmen on November 25, 1960, and soon became “symbols of both popular and feminist resistance." November 25 has since been designated the International Day for the Elimination of Violence against Women.

Palestinian resistance groups negotiated a four-day truce with Israel's wartime government brokered by Egypt and Qatar. The agreement is paving the way for prisoner exchanges from both sides and much-needed humanitarian aid for Gaza. The terms of the agreement are the following:
 
🟡 A ceasefire on both sides of all military actions by occupation forces in all areas of the Gaza Strip, including the movement of its military vehicles penetrating the Gaza Strip.
 
🟡 The entry of hundreds of trucks of humanitarian, relief, medical, and fuel aid into all areas of the Gaza Strip.  
 
🟡 The release of 50 Israeli women and children under the age of 19  in exchange for the release of 150 Palestinian women and children under the age of 19 years from Israeli prisons. 
 
🟡 No Israeli air traffic in the south for four days.  
 
🟡 No Israeli air traffic in the north for 6 hours daily, from 10:00 AM until 4:00 PM.  
 
🟡 During the ceasefire period, the Israelis should not attack or arrest any Palestinian across the Gaza Strip.  
 
🟡 Ensuring freedom of movement of Palestinians (from north to south) along Salah El-Din Street.

Tens of thousands of people in eastern Kenya have been left homeless after devastating floods hit Mororo. Video footage showed a scene of complete devastation with fields and villages submerged underwater as many people were forced to seek shelter in makeshift tents. 

The Kenya Red Cross Society reported that hundreds of homes had been swept away in coastal and northern areas of the country causing around 50 deaths and making 30,000 homeless. They also reported that 241 acres of agricultural farmland had been destroyed leading to the deaths of 1,000 livestock. The flooding also caused landslides which led to rail cargo services to the port city of Mombasa being canceled.

The extreme weather has been caused by the El Niño weather phenomenon which has brought very heavy rain following the worst drought in 40 years in the region which brought the region to the brink of famine. It is caused by warmer conditions in the Pacific Ocean but is also thought to be linked to climate change.

70 years ago today on 18 November 1953 the British Royal Air Force (RAF) started a brutal bombing campaign in colonial Kenya to crush the anti-colonial Mau Mau uprising. A total of 6 million bombs were dropped in what was known as Operation Mushroom. Attacks were initially aimed at forests where it was believed many Mau Mau fighters were hiding. Although the attacks were fairly haphazard the operation did drive a large number of Mau Mau fighters out of the forests.
 
Following this, the British built what they called "protection villages" to detain Kenyans they suspected of being Mau Mau fighters. Conditions were brutal and inhumane reflecting the barbaric nature of British colonialism. Although these brutal murderous tactics eventually led to the British declaring victory in October 1956 following the capture of Mau Mau Field Marshal Dedan Kimathi they could not hold back the tide of anti-colonialism and Kenya won its independence in 1960. Did you know that the Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic was the first country in the world to allow abortion on demand? 103 years ago today the Commissioners of Justice and Public Health signed an edict legalizing abortion on medical and social grounds. The law was passed in an attempt to combat the growing number of illegal abortions which often led to women having complications and dying. At the time, 50 % of women who had illegal abortions were infected and 4% died. 

However, the Bolshevik government did make it clear that it would like to eventually see abortion even performed legally disappear following the support it had introduced for working mothers that made it easier for them to balance child care and employment. They admitted however that due to the survival of some reactionary attitudes from the pre-revolutionary era and the difficult economic situation, it was necessary to legalize abortion to protect women's health. On the anniversary of the death of Yasser Arafat, the former chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization (PLO), we remember his infamous gun and olive branch speech. Arafat’s speech to the General Assembly on November 13, 1974, was a key point in the organization’s fight for Palestinian independence and self-determination. 
 
As part of their colonial occupation, Israel has been cutting down olive trees due to their association with Palestinian culture, replacing them with imported pine trees, and thus transforming the olive branch into a symbol of Palestinian resistance. Through the metaphor of an olive branch in one hand and a freedom fighter’s gun in the other, Arafat warned of the dangers of Zionism and its plan to eradicate Palestinian culture, identity, and history. 
 
The speech also marked a shift in the organization’s policy concerning the struggle against the state of Israel, with Arafat gradually considering a diplomatic approach, leading to him signing the Oslo Accords in 1993, effectively making “peace” with the Israeli occupation. The Oslo Accords have long been in tatters because of decades of Israeli violations of the agreement. In the 30 years since the signing of the Oslo Accords, the number of illegal settlements has at least tripled, and the Jewish settler population in the occupied West Bank has more than quadrupled. 
 
Today, the Palestinian masses largely reject Oslo, with resistance against the occupation intensifying, culminating in the offensive of October 7.

Yasser Arafat, former chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization (PLO), died on this day 19 years ago. Arafat remains one of the most iconic figures of the Palestinian liberation struggle to this day, and thanks to him, the Palestinian cause managed to gain international recognition.
 
In the 1950s, Arafat joined a group of Palestinians in founding the Palestinian National Liberation Movement (Fatah). He was elected chairman of the Executive Committee of the Palestine Liberation Organization (PLO) in February 1969.
 
On November 13, 1974, Arafat delivered his famous speech to the UN General Assembly in New York on behalf of the Palestinian people, concluding: “Today I have come bearing an olive branch and a freedom fighter’s gun. Do not let the olive branch fall from my hand.”
 
Arafat was elected President of the Palestinian National Authority (PNA) in general elections in 1996. However, after the Second Intifada broke out in 2000, Israeli forces and tanks besieged Arafat at his headquarters in Ramallah, accusing him of leading the Intifada. He later died in a French hospital from a sudden illness following the siege.

Bangladeshi police launch a fresh round of repression against garment workers who've been on strike for over a week. Workers demand a monthly minimum wage of 23,000 Tk ($209). 
 
Talks broke down two days ago after the government offered a mere 12,500 Tk ($112) as the new monthly wage. Unions reject the proposal and have returned to the streets.
 
Bangladesh's garment industry generates around $55 billion annually, supplying Western brands such as H&M, Walmart, and Zara. Meanwhile, the workers who produce these clothes are paid, on average, 8,300 Tk per month ($75).
 
The epicenter of the protests has been the capital, Dhaka, and the industrial city of Gazipur, where police say that at least 100 factories have been closed down by striking workers, who have also been blocking key highways leading daily marches. So far, three striking workers have been killed in the repression.
 
Workers are taking this action in response to sky-high inflation of more than 10% monthly due to an IMF 'structural adjustment' program this year that forced the country to end exchange rate controls.

On this day in 1918 revolutionary communist leader Karl Liebknecht declared Germany a Free Socialist Republic, saying "the day of the revolution has come".

Inspired by the Bolshevik Revolution a year earlier, Germany's uprising encompassed hundreds of thousands of workers, women and deserting soldiers who returned from the front fed up of being used as canon fodder by the rich. 


The monarchy was abolished and workers' councils swept the country, where women voted for the first time in German history. 

Within weeks, the SPD party, which today rules Germany, collaborated with the paramilitary Freikorps to crush the revolution, even bombing workers on general strike in Berlin. Leading members of the Freikorps were early Nazi Party members and the Freikorps itself would later be dissolved into the Nazi Party's paramilitary wing, the SA.

Garment workers in Bangladesh have been on strike since Monday (October 30th) and are on the streets again today, despite heavy repression, to demand a monthly minimum wage of Tk 23,000 (209 USD). Their current salary is Tk 8,300 (75 USD).

The country’s garment industry capitalists generate around 55 Billion USD annually in exports, mainly to the US and Europe, providing cheap clothes for the Western market. Meanwhile, 4 million garment workers, the majority of whom are women, face poverty wages and unsafe working conditions. 
 
This strike over wages has been triggered by rising inflation that has rendered essential goods unaffordable for many. The monthly inflation rate stands at almost 10% as the currency devaluation sets in, resulting from IMF loan conditions earlier this year that forced Bangladesh to scrap its fixed exchange rate system.

Why did anti-Apartheid revolutionary Nelson Mandela think that the struggle in Palestine, in many ways mirrored the South African liberation struggle? The 1990 town hall meeting in New York where Mandela expressed his views formed part of his first visit to the US following his release from prison. The town hall meeting took place long before the world had embraced Nelson Mandela as a “giant of justice.” Also, back then, in the West, it was unfashionable and unpopular to support the Palestinians, with many considering Mandela’s statements “controversial,” but he stood firm in his support of the Palestinian cause.

Security forces responded with tear gas as protesters threw stones, lit tires, and blocked several roads.
 
Concerned about the potential environmental damage and loss of control of their country's resources, the protesters, including many Indigenous people, are demanding the repeal of a contract allowing continued operations at the largest copper mine in Central America, representing more than 75% of Panama’s exports. Watch as an estimated 100,000 Icelandic women go on a nationwide 24-hour strike in the biggest walkout since 1975. Women refused to cook, clean, or do unpaid care work, women took to the streets demanding greater gender equality and protesting against the gender pay gap, gender-based violence, and sexual violence. 

Known as “women’s day off” or “Kvennafrí” in Icelandic, it was the seventh such strike since the first one took place in 1975. In a country where 90% of workers are unionized, unions called on women and non-binary people to refuse to perform paid and unpaid work, including chores. Icelanders awoke to all-male news teams with public transport delayed, hospitals understaffed, and hotel rooms uncleaned as the women’s strike shut down the island nation.
 
In the country with a population of over 372,000 people, more than a quarter of the country gathered in the capital’s city center to mark the landmark event. The strike was acknowledged by government departments and supported by the largest federation of public sector unions, the Federation of the Public Workers Union in Iceland (BSRB) along with the Icelandic Nurses’ Association and the Icelandic Association of Women’s Associations.

US socialist, journalist, and writer John Reed was born today in 1887. His unwavering commitment to the international communist cause profoundly shaped his life and work.
 
Reed reported on striking silk workers in New Jersey for the socialist magazine "The Masses" and was deeply affected by the police crackdown on the strikers. Reed's career later led him to Europe during WWI, and later to Russia in 1917. He witnessed the October Revolution and documented his firsthand experiences in his masterpiece "Ten Days That Shook the World." 
 
Upon his return to the US, he played a pivotal role in founding the Communist Labor Party. However, when the US government issued an order for his arrest due to his communist affiliations, Reed had to flee to Russia, where he served as an American delegate at the Second Congress of the Communist International in 1920.
 
At the age of 32 in 1920, Reed succumbed to typhus while in Russia. His final resting place is beside Soviet heroes.

Happy birthday to Black Panther Party (BPP) co-founder and chairman Bobby Seale!
 
When Seale began attending Merritt College in Oakland, California, he was exposed to Black radical politics and first met Huey Newton. Inspired by Malcolm X, revolutionary independence movements in Africa, and anti-colonial thinkers such as Frantz Fanon, Seale, and Newton founded the Black Panther Party for Self-Defense in 1966. While working at a War on Poverty program, he and Newton wrote the revolutionary ten-point program that laid the groundwork for the BPP's radical legacy as a movement fighting to achieve Black liberation through revolutionary socialism.
 
In 1968, Seale was arrested, along with seven other activists, during protests at the Democratic National Convention in Chicago, becoming one of the infamous Chicago Eight defendants. During the trial, Seale was repeatedly denied the right to represent himself, and the presiding judge, Julius Hoffmann, ordered him bound and gagged. He was ultimately sentenced to four years in prison for contempt of court. In an interview with the Guardian, Seale recalled: "All I did in Chicago was to exercise my legal right to speak on my own behalf, and I was given four years in jail as a result. But I think the most serious injustice perpetrated by the court system in America is the inability of a Black man to get a jury of his peers."
 
After his release from jail, Seale found the BPP significantly weakened due to arrests, killings, and internal conflicts caused by the FBI's efforts to neutralize the organization. In an attempt to enter electoral politics, Seale ran for mayor of Oakland in 1973, finishing second and prompting a runoff election, which he ultimately lost.
 
In 1974, Seale resigned as chairman of the BPP. However, to this day, he remains politically active, advocating for groups that support social justice, and is an influential figure in the fight for equality and justice.

As Israel continues its brutal repression, murder, and colonial domination of the Palestinian people a fruit has become a surprising symbol of Palestinian resistance. Following the aftermath of the 1967 Six-Day War, the Israeli authorities banned all public displays of the Palestinian flag with the possibility of imprisonment for those who defied the ban. Instead of flying their national flag, Palestinians are increasingly using watermelons as a form of public defiance against the occupation.
 
Mirroring the colors of the Palestinian flag red, black, white, and green, the watermelon has been used by artists as a symbol of resistance for decades, while ordinary Palestinians carried slices of the fruit with them as a small act of opposition to colonial rule. In 2021, the watermelon became increasingly prominent as a symbol of resistance among Palestinians on social media following the Israeli attacks on Gaza. In January, far-right Israeli Security Minister Itamar Ben-Gvir told police to confiscate Palestinian flags in public places and in June the Israeli Parliament the Knesset gave preliminary approval for a bill outlawing the flag in all state-funded institutions. Responding to this, a grassroots Arab-Israeli peace organization, Zazim placed the flag in watermelon form on taxis in Tel Aviv. With the ongoing Israeli assault on Gaza and an expected ground invasion set to begin the watermelon as a symbol of Palestinian resistance is more important than ever.

On this day 50 years ago, the war known in Egypt and Syria as the Ramadan and October Liberation War, respectively, and in Israel as the Yom Kippur War, began. The war lasted two weeks and five days and ultimately ended in defeat for Egypt and Syria on October 25, 1973. 
 
The war started with a two-pronged surprise attack by Syrian and Egyptian forces against Israeli positions in the Golan and on the Sinai Peninsula. In the Sinai Peninsula, the Israelis had created a fortification line across the canal's eastern bank known as the Bar Lev line, which gave them advanced notice that an attack was taking place. 
 
Under constant artillery bombardment and aerial strikes, the Egyptian forces crossed the Suez Canal in rubber dinghies, eventually reaching the lower embankment of the sand berm that made up the Israeli fortifications.

Within two hours of the start of hostilities, the Egyptian forces managed to climb up to the top of the line, breach its first defensive perimeter, and continue onwards across the desert. They also used gasoline-fueled water pumps to pump out the sand, allowing tanks and vehicles to cross after the first assault.
 
Israel maintained its occupation of the Syrian Golan Heights, which it had acquired following the 1967 war, while Egypt managed to negotiate an Israeli withdrawal from the Sinai as part of a peace settlement that also included a total normalization of relations between the two countries. Anwar Sadat, the president of Egypt at the time, thus broke with the anti-colonial and anti-Zionist policies of Egypt advocated by his predecessor, Gamal Abdel Nasser.

Today marks the anniversary of the historic meeting of Cuban revolutionary leader Fidel Castro and Black revolutionary Malcolm X in Harlem, New York, in 1960. The meeting was like no other, do you know why? 
 
A year after the Cuban Revolution, Castro and his delegation arrived in New York to attend the UN General Assembly. However, the management of the Manhattan hotel where the delegation had made reservations refused to accommodate them, following pressure from the US government that had already convinced other hotels to reject the Cubans. Upon learning of their situation, Malcolm X invited them to come uptown to Harlem and stay at the Black-owned Hotel Theresa, where he assured them, they would be welcomed with open arms.
 
The people of Harlem warmly received the 34-year-old Cuban revolutionary leader, crowds gathering round-the-clock in front of the hotel. To them, Castro was the bearded revolutionary who had boldly defied white America, and his stay in Harlem symbolized the shared struggle of African Americans with the rest of the Third World against racism, colonialism, and imperialism.
 
Castro pointed out that Black people in the United States weren't as influenced by the government's anti-Cuban propaganda as white Americans. Castro also highlighted the progress in revolutionary Cuba to eliminate racial discrimination, emphasizing that Cubans, Africans, and Black Americans were all in the same struggle. 
 
He said, "I feel as if I were in Cuba now. I feel very warm here." In response, Malcolm X acknowledged that it was indeed true that "We in Harlem are not addicted to all the propaganda the US government puts out." They then embraced, and Malcolm X noted, "As long as Uncle Sam is against you, you know you're a good man."

Vietnam's Independence Day has since been celebrated with parades honoring the resistance forces in Hanoi.

Today in 1913, the five-month-long Dublin lockout began, involving 20,000 workers. Often wrongly categorized as a strike it was a callous attempt by Ireland's capitalist class to starve workers into submission and prevent them from joining the growing Irish Transport and General Workers Union (ITGWU). Impoverished workers living in some of Europe's worst conditions were locked out of their workplaces while British and Irish strikebreaking workers or "scabs" replaced them.

The story is a pioneering attempt at building working-class unity and one big union representing all workers as a step towards overthrowing capitalism and establishing a workers' republic in Ireland. After betrayal by Britain's trade union leadership, Irish workers would lose this battle. But out of its ashes, a growing trade union movement and the Irish Citizen's Army were born, which would lead the first major challenge to British rule three years later.

Today is the anniversary of Nat Turner's 1831 slave rebellion, one of the most significant slave uprisings in US history. On August 21, 1831, Turner, an enslaved preacher, led a 3-day uprising in Southampton County, Virginia. Turner evaded capture for six weeks but was eventually put on trial, convicted, and executed on 11 November 1831. His body was dissected and his skin was sold to make souvenir purses. It would take a full civil war decades later to defeat the evil system of slavery in the US.

On this day, 91 years ago, the Italian anarchist socialist theorist and militant revolutionary Errico Malatesta died in Rome. He was described by friends and foes alike as the greatest Italian revolutionary of his generation.

Malatesta led an armed insurrection with about thirty comrades in the province of Benevento, capturing two villages from the ruling monarchy in southern Italy. Due to the quick arrival of troops, the uprising was soon crushed. 

Malatesta was imprisoned for 16 months before being released into exile, living in Switzerland, France, Romania, England, Argentina, the US, the Netherlands, and Egypt, where he organized a group of fighters to oppose the British during the Anglo-Egyptian War in 1882.

A blossoming anarchist movement in Italy and a collapsing government lured Malatesta back to his homeland in 1898, where he was soon arrested following clashes. He spent his last years working as an electrician and passed away in 1932, suffering from bronchial pneumonia.

Two years ago today, one of the last Auschwitz survivors, communist Esther Béjarano, died at the age of 96. Thousands of anti-fascists attended her funeral in her hometown of Hamburg, Germany.
 
After her deportation to the Auschwitz death camp in 1943, Béjarano was forced by the Nazis to play the accordion in the girls' orchestra. On May 3, 1945, in Lübz, Béjarano was liberated by the Soviet Red Army and US forces.
 
After the war, she moved first to Palestine, then in 1960 to Hamburg, where she was active for decades against fascism. Béjarano was also known for her solidarity with the Palestinian liberation struggle.
 
Her later life was marked by her fight against the emergence of new fascist parties and movements in Germany, focusing primarily on young people, to whom she appealed: "You are not to blame for what happened, but you are guilty if you don't care."

Have you seen this series of communist paintings by Mexico's most important painter, Frida Kahlo? Her self-portrait with Joseph Stalin may be glossed over by liberal whitewashing, but Kahlo's Communist legacy still shines through her commercialization.
 
At an early age, Kahlo joined the Mexican Communist Party's youth group and officially entered the party in 1927. She fought in labor unions, secured Spanish communist refugees who fought in the civil war asylum in Mexico, and raised funds for Spanish Republicans fighting Franco.
 
She worked for the cultural revival of Mexico by celebrating indigenous culture through her art. She also dismantled traditional expectations in her art by addressing taboo topics such as gender, bisexuality, disability, mental health, and more.
 
Frida Kahlo had taken part, against medical advice, in a protest against the US invasion of the leftist government in Guatemala in 1954. During this time, she got pneumonia, from which she would not recover.

On this day, the Marxist feminist theorist and revolutionary Clara Zetkin died in exile in the Soviet Union in 1933. Her pioneering work in the international women's movement continues to shape today's class struggle and the fight for women's liberation.

During Zetkin's revolutionary period, she served as the editor of the socialist women's magazine "Die Gleichheit" from 1892 to 1917 and on the executive committee of the Third International from 1921.

Zetkin played a central role in founding the communist Spartacus League, which later evolved into the German Communist Party. She represented the party in Parliament until the Nazi takeover, which forced her into exile.

One of Zetkin's significant contributions is her notable work, "Lenin on the Woman Question," published in 1920. Zetkin's core analyses focus on the active participation of women in revolutionary leadership and the emancipation of women as an essential basis for building a socialist society.

On Pride Month, we remember Willem Arondeus, a Dutch artist, author, and anti-Nazi resistance fighter, who deserves recognition for his remarkable contributions during World War II. Happy birthday Che Guevara, the Marxist icon par excellence, who changed the world forever during his short life! Starting as a humanitarian doctor, forged by the catastrophic consequences of capitalism in Latin America, and immortalized in the communist struggle – for Che Guevara, words and deeds were the same.
 
In 1953, bidding farewell to his parents, Guevara started with his legendary motorcycle trip across Latin America. He first encountered his future comrade-in-arms in Mexico, the young Fidel Castro, preparing for the guerrilla struggle in Cuba.
 
Years of guerrilla warfare followed, during which Che became the comandante of the Cuban revolutionaries, whose victory catapulted him onto the world stage. However, his revolutionary urge was not satisfied, and he once again threw himself into the guerrilla fight.
 
When the Bolivian army captured Guevara after a fierce battle in 1967, his captors executed him on the spot, following orders from the CIA. The murder made him immortal.

PDR Yemen was governed during this period by Salim Rubai Ali, who received his political education at a Maoist commune in Hadhramawt province.

Did you know that between 1969-1978, the People's Democratic Republic of Yemen was influenced by Maoism?  

Despite the commonly held belief that PDR Yemen was nothing but a Soviet satellite state, it had a brief period between 1969 - 1978 where Maoist China more influenced the country than the Soviet Union. In this period, Yemen had a very small industrialized proletariat and relied on the peasantry for economic development. 

Yemen's socialists successfully built a welfare state with high-quality education, guaranteed employment, and subsidized housing.

On this day in 1980, revolutionary socialist, guerrilla intellectual, and pan-African activist Walter Rodney was assassinated by a car bomb, an attack widely believed to have been a political assassination orchestrated by the state. 
 
In his landmark book “How Europe Underdeveloped Africa,” Rodney explained how European “development” was the flip side of African “underdevelopment.” He methodically examined how centuries of European colonial exploitation have exhausted Africa’s wealth while enriching the West. 
 
Born into a working-class family in British Guyana in the 1960s, Rodney taught at Jamaica’s University of the West Indies while holding public lectures on the streets known as “groundings.” Crowds gathered to discuss radical political ideas, and these sessions played a vital role in developing revolutionary thinking in the Caribbean.

In 1968, Rodney was banned from Jamaica, forcing him to return to his home country, Guyana.

Today is Philippines Independence Day commemorating the country's declaration of Independence from Spain in 1898. It is marked with a public reading of the declaration in Kawait, where it was first read 105 years ago at the Aguinaldo Shrine. Parades also take place across the country, including in the capital Manilla where the President makes a speech followed by a 21-gun salute.
 
Inspired by the anti-colonial movement in another Spanish colony, Cuba, the Philippines Revolution started in 1896, led by a revolutionary group known as the Kaptipunan. However, following a nationwide armed revolt, a brutal internal power struggle led to a bourgeois betrayal of the revolutionary movement resulting in numerous setbacks.
 
Although victory over the Spanish colonists was achieved, the Filipino people were betrayed not just by their bourgeois leaders but by the US, who effectively took over as colonialists from the Spanish. It would take many decades before the Filipino people were finally free.

Today is the anniversary of the CIA's first Latin American coup: the 1954 coup in Guatemala that overthrew the democratically elected left-leaning president Jacobo Árbenz and replaced him with a brutal 40-year US-backed military dictatorship that would oversee the torture and mass murder of hundreds of thousands of people, mostly leftists, as well as the genocide of Guatemala's Indigenous people, the Maya.
 
Upon taking office, Árbenz proposed land reforms that would redistribute land, which was seen as a threat to the interests of the powerful US-based United Fruit Company. Despite his moderate leftist policies, he was labeled a communist by Washington, and the US company lobbied for his removal.

The support of brutal right-wing military coups, mostly against communist or left-leaning forces, in Latin America became one of the most used weapons of US imperialism. As this map shows, the coup set the course for US imperialism strategy across the continent.

On this day 58 years ago, the people of Oman's Dhofar province ignited their armed struggle. Motivated by Arab nationalist sentiment, the struggle aimed to overthrow the feudal Sultan Said bin Taimur, who had treated Dhofar and its inhabitants as his domain for a significant period.

In 1968, taking inspiration from the previous year's success of the Yemeni National Liberation Front, the Dhofar Liberation Front changed its name to the Popular Front for the Liberation of Oman and the Arabian Gulf (PFLOAG) and officially embraced Marxism-Leninism as its fundamental ideology.

Notably, the PFLOAG drew considerable inspiration from Maoist theory and the People's Republic of China, trying to position the Omani people's struggle within the broader context of the decolonization movement.

The PFLOAG fought for the liberation and empowerment of women, advocated for free education, and worked towards the establishment of schools, hospitals, and essential infrastructure throughout Dhofar province.

On this day, the cries of the Gazan child, Huda Ghalia, 11 years old, echoed around the world after the killing of her family by the Israeli air forces on the beach of Beit Lahiya in Gaza in 2006.
 
Huda's life was turned upside down when she witnessed the killing of her father and five of her siblings by a shell from an Israeli barge that targeted them while they were on a family trip to the beach.  
 
A few years later, one of her sisters and her husband were killed during the Israeli aggression on Gaza in 2008-2009, adding a new page to their tragic story.
 
In the months that followed the incident, human rights centers documented the testimonies of Huda and the rest of her surviving family in their reports. However, as Hoda says, "We did not achieve practical results that would lead to holding Israel accountable for its crimes."
 
In 2017, Huda managed to obtain a law degree and she still hopes to be able to file a case against the Israeli army in an international court.

On this day, 1989, the Afro-Trinidadian socialist, historian, and writer C. L. R. James, best known for his seminal books "World Revolution" and "The Black Jacobins," passed away at 88 in his home in London. 
 
In 1938, James first published "The Black Jacobins" – the book was taken up over time by various movements - as a corrective to Eurocentric historians, an analysis of colonial capitalism, and a theory of revolution. The book tells the story of the Haitian Revolution of 1791 to 1804, the only slave revolution that led to establishing of an independent state.
 
James was also a pioneer in re-exploring history through unconventional methods. For example, he utilized the sport of cricket to trace British colonial history in his work "Beyond a Boundary."
 
C. L. R. James' contributions have left a lasting legacy. His comprehensive approach to understanding the world, combining literature, sports, politics, and music, challenged conventional notions and offered a unique perspective.

On this day 32 years ago, Eritrea finally won independence when the Marxist guerrilla group Eritrean People's Liberation Front marched into the capital after a 30-year war. 

The narrow strip of land on the Red Sea was fiercely contested for centuries. In the Middle Ages, the territory of present-day Eritrea was part of the Abyssinia Empire, a monarchy in East Africa whose territory included present-day Ethiopia.

In the mid-16th century, the Ottomans occupied the area that is now Eritrea. After the Ottoman Empire crumbled in the 19th century, Italy colonized the region in 1890 but lost its rule to Britain during World War II. A UN plan which tried to pave the way for Eritrean independence in 1952 failed when Eritrea was again forced into the Empire of Abyssinia as a province in 1960. 

The Eritrean Liberation Front emerged in 1961, whose liberation struggle ended in independence in 1991. In a 1993 UN referendum, 99.8% of Eritreans voted for independence.

Today marks the 103rd anniversary of the founding of the Indonesian Communist Party in 1920 – at one point, the largest communist party outside of China and the USSR. The PKI was brutally wiped out during the US-led Cold War anti-communist frenzy. CIA reports described the killings as one of the worst mass murders of the 20th century.
 
The PKI thrived in the labor movement, gaining support from small farmers and had its own women's organization. Following a failed coup in 1965, communism was banned in Indonesia as a political movement and ideology. The ban on the PKI remains in place to this day.

On this day in 1942, the Yugoslav antifascist partisan, Stjepan Filipović, was executed by the Nazis in what is modern-day Serbia.
 
Filipović had been a key figure in the 1941 partisan uprising against the Nazi occupation forces and their collaborators. However, in 1942, he was captured by Chetnik collaborators in Valjevo and publicly hung.
 
Even as he was being dragged through the streets of the city, Filipović remained defiant, shouting slogans in support of the partisan resistance. His final words were "Death to fascism, freedom to the people!."
 
This slogan became a rallying cry for the partisan movement and a symbol of resistance against Nazi occupation. Despite Filipović's death, the partisans continued their struggle against fascism and were ultimately successful in liberating Yugoslavia in 1945.

Centuries of colonial rule and a genocidal occupation finally ended for East Timor on this day in 2002, becoming the first new sovereign state of the 21st century. Independence was won through the resistance led by socialist revolutionary guerrillas and international pressure.

Portugal colonized East Timor in the 16th century, while the Dutch colonized the western part, which later became Indonesia. Portugal abandoned their colony in 1974 following the Carnation Revolution. The Marxist-Leninist Revolutionary Front for an Independent East Timor (FRETILIN) declared independence in 1975, leading to an Indonesian invasion to prevent a communist state, causing the death of up to 20% of the population.

FRETILIN's guerrilla wing fought relentlessly, inspired by Mao Zedong, Amilcar Cabral, and Cuba's anti-imperialist resistance. In 1998, a popular uprising in Indonesia forced dictator Suharto to resign. This paved the way for a referendum, resulting in a majority voting for independence.

Happy birthday to the Vietnamese national liberation leader and communist revolutionary, Ho Chi Minh! Under his leadership, the Vietnamese Liberation Front was formed, which kicked out the French colonialists and US imperialists from Vietnam.

He lived in New York, London, and Paris and became involved in the global socialist movement. In France, he even became a founding member of the French Communist Party.

Today's Victory Day, marking the defeat of Nazi Germany, we remember one of the most famous moments from newly liberated Berlin. The video shows Maria Limanskaya, a young Red Army woman, dancing and directing traffic in front of the Brandenburg Gate.

Her performance was captured on film by a cameraman named Anatoly Aronov and immediately went viral around the world.

Maria Limanskaya was awarded the medals: "For the Liberation of Warsaw", "For the Capture of Berlin" and "For Victory over Germany". She is still alive today at the age of 99 years.

As we approach the annual Liberation Day on May 8, we travel back in time with archival footage that captures the final moments of World War II, as the Red Army pushed back the Nazi Wehrmacht from Stalingrad to Berlin.

Ahead of May 8, 1945, Joseph Goebbels and Martin Bormann, who assumed power over the Wehrmacht after Hitler's suicide, refused to surrender unconditionally. In response, the Soviets launched a final assault on the Reich Chancellery, where the remnants of the fascist forces had entrenched themselves.

On May 2, the fascists acknowledged their defeat with a radio message proclaiming, "We cease hostilities." Finally, on May 8, the Allied High Command met with the remnants of the fascist military to sign the document of unconditional surrender.

During the Final Battle of Berlin, according to Soviet data, almost half a million German soldiers lost their lives. Declassified Soviet archive documents reveal that at least 81,116 Red Army soldiers were killed in the battle.

Today marks the 26th anniversary of the death of Paulo Freire, a Brazilian Marxist educator and philosopher. Freire was known for his influential book Pedagogy of the Oppressed (1970), in which he theorized how oppressed people could be empowered by revolutionized education.

His innovative teaching methods emphasized active student participation and encouraged critical questioning of the teacher. As a result, his students were able to achieve literacy after only 30 hours of lessons.

Freire believed that socialism and Marxism provided a framework for understanding and challenging systems of oppression. He argued that education could be a tool for social change, and teachers should work to create a more equal society. 

Despite facing repression and censorship from right-wing forces in Brazil and worldwide, Freire's work continues to inspire educators and activists while his vision remains as relevant today as ever in the struggle for social justice.

Connolly spent seven years in the US, where he co-founded the Industrial Workers' of the World (IWW), some of whose members had been involved in organizing the first May Day protest in Chicago in 1886.

In 1913 he organized the most significant strike in Irish history, the Dublin Lockout, and later helped lead the 1916 Easter Rising which despite being brutally crushed and ending in his execution, would set off a chain of events that would eventually expel Britain from the 26 counties that today makeup the Republic of Ireland.

On this day in history Antonio Gramsci, the influential Italian Marxist theorist, intellectual, and one of the leaders of the Italian Communist Party, passed away. ⁠

His life was cut short by the fascist regime of Benito Mussolini, who outlawed communism and arrested Gramsci. He was sentenced to 11 years in prison, where he died on April 27, 1937. Despite being one of the greatest minds of his time, Gramsci's ideas were considered a threat to the fascist government.

During his trial, the prosecutor urged the court to "prevent this brain from functioning for twenty years," and even Mussolini himself acknowledged Gramsci's powerful intellect. During his time in prison, Gramsci filled over 30 notebooks with his writings, later entitled "The Prison Notebooks," which would go on to become an important contribution to Marxist theory.

Antonio Gramsci's contributions to Marxist theory have been widely studied and debated, and his ideas continue to have relevance today.

The Council also urged all nations to uphold their legal obligations by not recognizing or assisting Israel's violation of international laws, particularly the taking of territory through the use of force.

Today, we celebrate the Italian victory over fascism and German occupation, known as Liberation Day in Italy. To mark this historic occasion, we present an album of colorized images capturing the spirit of the antifascist resistance. 

In 1945, communist-led antifascist partisans liberated Northern Milan and Turin from the grasp of Hitler’s army and Benito Mussolini’s loyalists after a working-class uprising.⁠ One of the greatest myths about WWII is that Allied armies led by the US liberated Europe from Nazism. Many national liberation movements were vital in driving the Nazis out of their countries.

One of the most inspiring stories comes from Italy, where a guerrilla army of 300,000, known as the partisans, fought the Nazis and Italian fascists behind the front lines.⁠ Three days after liberating Milan and Turin, the partisans captured and executed Benito Mussolini and his mistress, hanging them upside down in Milan’s Piazzale Loreto, marking the end of over 20 years of fascism.

The conference expressed opposition to imperialism, racism, colonialism, and militarism. After  WWII,  colonized countries  launched their own movement. They expressed a desire for democracy, equality and freedom from exploitation. 

Today, former colonial countries worldwide are still struggling with the impact of colonialism.

As the armed conflict rages on, food costs have skyrocketed, with many local reports indicating that staple food prices have doubled. Sudan has already suffered a food crisis, with the UN estimating in 2022 that at least three million children under five are malnourished.

To commemorate of Ireland's single most famous challenge to British imperialism, the 1916 Easter Rising, we have colorized pictures of this historic event. 

The Easter Rising sparked the process that would eventually expel Britain from 26 Irish counties, today the Republic of Ireland.
The rebellion was launched by the Irish Volunteers and James Connolly's socialist Irish Citizen's Army. With England bogged down with WWI, their slogan was: "England’s difficulty is Ireland’s opportunity".

On Easter Monday, Patrick Pearse declared the "Irish Republic" and read the provisional government's proclamation which declared equality for all Ireland's people.

By the fifth day, the British had brutally crushed the rising. Its leaders were executed and Connolly was so badly beaten that British soldiers had to tie him upright to a chair so they could shoot him.

The uprising by a few Irish rebels inspired a nationwide insurrection and led to the Irish War of Independence.

On the anniversary of her death, we remember the revolutionary artist Nina Simone. Simone used her voice and platform as a superstar to speak out against injustice and her songs became anthems of resistance and struggle for the Black liberation movement and oppressed people worldwide.
 
Simone's music was deeply political, calling for an end to racism, poverty, and oppression. Her song "Mississippi Goddam" was a direct response to the 1963 murder of civil rights activist Medgar Evers by white supremacists, and the racist bombing of the 16th Street Baptist Church in Alabama in the same year. 

Simone faced constant discrimination and marginalization in the music industry, especially because of her outspoken political beliefs and she was often overlooked by mainstream radio and record labels. However, Simone persevered and continued to create music that reflected her values and beliefs, ultimately becoming a revered figure in the world of music and activism.

Happy birthday to Rosario Sánchez Mora, the woman who literally blew up fascists in the Spanish Civil War! 

Aged only 17 years old, she joined the revolutionary militias to resist Franco’s fascist army and fought on the front lines defending Madrid. Mora was known for her mastery of explosives, which earned her the nickname ‘the Dynamiter.’

After the defeat of the Republic, the Fascists captured Mora and sentenced her to death. She was imprisoned with other anarchist, socialist, and communist women, who were subjected to torture, murder, and separation from their children.

Despite all the hardships, Sánchez Mora was eventually released due to overcrowding in  political prisons. She made a living by selling cigarettes in Madrid. She continued to fight for what she believed in until her death on April 17, 2008.

On this day, 59 years ago, Zimbabwe's war of independence began, signaling the end of British colonial rule. To commemorate this anniversary, we have gathered a collection of solidarity posters from the Global South that reflect the anti-colonial fighting spirit of the time.

During the conflict, the Zimbabwe People's Revolutionary Army (ZIPRA) and the Zimbabwe African National Liberation Army (ZANLA) fought against the colonial forces, ultimately forcing the white minority government to the negotiation table in 1979. The struggle led to the independence of Zimbabwe in 1980, with Robert Mugabe, a Marxist-Leninist, serving as the country's first black Prime Minister.

The oppressive colonial rule imposed apartheid on Black Africans, relegating them to second-class citizens in their own country. They were denied access to education, healthcare, and fundamental human rights while being forced to work on farms and mines for meager wages while their white oppressors enjoyed a luxurious lifestyle.

The FARC-EP guerrilla faction, known as the "Central General Staff," hosted an event that drew in thousands of supporters, where they announced negotiations with the Colombian government in May. Footage shows armed men and women surrounded by social organizations, farmers, and locals.

President Petro's campaign for "Total Peace" aims to negotiate with organized armed groups, including the Communist National Liberation Army (ELN). A bilateral ceasefire is in place with the FARC group, but it has been fragile, with reports of clashes between guerrillas and government troops.

Today is the 62nd anniversary of when Cuba humiliated imperialism by defeating a U.S.-backed invasion at the Bay of Pigs (Playa Girón) in 1961.⁠ We colorized pictures that capture the essence of this historic battle. 

The Bay of Pigs invasion, also known as Playa Girón, orchestrated and armed by the CIA to assassinate Fidel Castro and destroy the revolution, was crushed within a mere three days. This defeat resulted in almost 100 invaders losing their lives, while over 1,000 were captured.

Fidel Castro bravely stood alongside Cuban soldiers on the frontlines directing the military. Cuba’s resistance to the invasion marked one of the first significant defeats of U.S. imperialism in Latin America, strengthening the revolution which survives to this day.

62 years ago today, the U.S. launched the Bay of Pigs invasion to crush the Cuban revolution. Fidel Castro led the Cuban masses to sensationally defeat the CIA’s mercenaries in just 72 hours. Watch Ollie Vargas break down what happened. ☝️

106 years ago today legendary Russian revolutionary Bolshevik leader Vladimir Lenin returned to his homeland arriving at Finland station in Petrograd in what was a key moment in Russian and world history leading to the Great October Socialist Revolution.  

Following 17 years of exile, Lenin arrived on April 16 after a long train journey from Zurich determined to overthrow the failed corrupt Provisional government and create a "dictatorship of the proletariat".

Addressing thousands of his supporters Lenin called he Bolshevik Party to use armed force to overthrow the Provisional government formed after the abdication of Tsar Nicholas II. He also called for workers to seize the factories and for peasants to take the land as well as an end to Russian involvement in the First World War.

Later that year led by Lenin and the Bolsheviks, and organized in Soviets the Russian working class made history by overthrowing the Provisional government and seizing power in the world's first ever socialist revolution.

On a day like today in 1930, José Carlos Mariátegui, the iconic Peruvian Marxist thinker, passed away. Despite his early death, Mariátegui left an indelible mark on the history and struggle of Latin America.

Mariátegui was a gifted journalist, a brilliant philosopher, and an unapologetic Marxist revolutionary. He saw the world not as it was, but as it could be, and he devoted himself to the task of building socialism.

Mariátegui's vision of socialism was not a mere copy of the European model. Instead, he believed that the struggle for socialism in Latin America must be born out of the particular realities of their respective people and land.

Mariátegui's Marxist analysis of the "Peruvian reality" has become the foundation of the socialist and communist movements throughout Latin America today. His founding of the Peruvian Communist Party marked him as a pioneer of communism on the Latin American continent.

On this day 37 years ago, French feminist and author Simone de Beauvoir passed away. Her seminal work, “The Second Sex,” challenged patriarchal norms and made her one of the most famous intellectuals in France.

Her theory was not limited to women’s rights but was part of a broader struggle against capitalist exploitation and oppression. De Beauvoir challenged the patriarchal norms of her time and argued that women were oppressed by their gender-specific relationship with society, capital, and men.

During the Nazi occupation of France, De Beauvoir was active in the resistance group “Socialism and Liberty,” using her writing skills to produce anti-Nazi propaganda and working with underground networks to distribute it.

Later, De Beauvoir joined the fight for Algerian liberation against French colonialism. She signed the influential “Manifesto of 121,” calling for self-determination for Algerians, which publication was suppressed in France by the government.

Happy birthday to Tanzania's anti-imperialist, socialist, pan-African former President, Julius Nyerere, born 101 years ago today. 

Nyerere helped lead his country to independence from Britain and became President of the successor state to Tanganyika, Tanzania, from 1964 to 1985.

Nyerere developed his own political philosophy known as Ujamaa, establishing a socialist economic system based upon traditional African culture and values. This included the nationalization of banks, major industries and companies as well as the establishment of collective farms.

Nyerere also introduced free and universal education, radically improving his country's literacy rate, and vastly improved access to health care for the majority Tanzanians. He instilled a sense of national pride among Tanzania’s diverse tribes, preventing tribal conflicts. 

Under his leadership, Tanzania also became a key player in the international resistance to the apartheid regime in South Africa.

Today marks the 62nd anniversary of the historic achievement of Soviet pilot and cosmonaut Yuri Gagarin, who became the first person ever to orbit the Earth. Gagarin's mission was a significant milestone for the Soviet Union, as it beat the U.S. in the race to send a human to space.

Soviet archive footage shows Gagarin moments before his liftoff and enthusiastic celebrations in Moscow upon his homecoming. Gagarin's famous words after his space mission, "Looking at the earth from afar, you realize it is too small for conflict and just big enough for cooperation," still ring true today.

Gagarin's mission into space propelled him to global fame, making him a worldwide icon. He was also recognized as a hero by the Soviet Union and was awarded the "Order of Lenin" for his remarkable accomplishments.

Filipinos have been protesting about the largest-ever joint Philippines-U.S. military exercises. Activists carried banners with slogans such as “U.S. troops out now” and “No to U.S. war games” outside Camp Aguinaldo in the eastern suburbs of the capital, Manila.

The Balikatan exercises will last three days, involving 17,000 troops, including 12,000 from the U.S. The government recently approved more U.S. military bases under the Enhanced Defense Cooperation Agreement. Protesters fear the military exercises will likely increase tensions between the U.S. and China.

Irish Republican youths threw petrol bombs and other missiles at a police land rover in the Creggan area of Derry. They were furious that a Republican march had been banned. 

The march organized by the Derry 1916 Commemoration Committee went ahead regardless and the Police Service of Northern Ireland (PSNI) monitored it from a distance. The parade started in the Central Drive area of the city before moving on to the City Cemetery, where the PSNI vehicle was attacked with petrol bombs and fireworks before driving off in flames. 

The PSNI have now closed the cemetery close to the attack, claiming an explosive device is in the area. Dissident Republicans represented at the Derry march were commemorating the 1916 Easter Rising against British colonial rule and have never accepted The Good Friday Agreement.

Today in 2002, right-wing forces backed by the U.S. attempted to overthrow former Venezuelan President Hugo Chavez, ultimately falling against popular resistance. Watch this powerful speech of the Bolivarian revolutionary Hugo Chavez, rallying thousands against imperialism.

On April 11, 2002, the Venezuelan elite, the Church, and some military members organized a coup against then-President Hugo Chavez. However, the Venezuelan people swarmed the streets to protect the Bolivarian revolution and overpowered the US-backed right-wing coup. 

The coup plotter aimed to form a de facto government headed by Pedro Carmona, a business mogul and former president of the chambers of commerce, which would dissolve all other state powers and local authorities.

The people brought Hugo Chavez back to power in just 47 hours. The counterrevolutionary offensive backfired, as mass mobilization politicized additional segments of the population, who also organized themselves into Bolivarian collectives.

On this day 104 years ago, Mexican revolutionary leader Emiliano Zapata was assassinated by an undercover army officer. Zapata was so hated by the Mexican elite and so loved by the working class that it was thought necessary to display his body for 24 hours and photograph it to prove he was dead.

Zapata grew up in a rural community and was involved in the Mexican revolution when it began in 1910 leading a peasant revolt in Morelos#. He helped form the Liberation Army of the South soon becoming it's leader calling for reforms that would give more land and power to the peasants.

Today his legacy lives on through Zapatista revolutionary groups that emerged in the mid 1990s fighting for land reform and justice such as the National Zapatista Liberation Army (EZLN).

25 years ago today the Good Friday Agreement was signed ending the conflict known as "the troubles". 

To remember the critical role Ireland's militant struggle against British rule played in securing the deal, here is an album that captures that era of Irish resistance.

30 years ago today, one of South Africa's most iconic figures, the communist revolutionary Chris Hani, was assassinated.

Born Martin Thembisile Hani, he is remembered as the charming, passionate and charismatic General Secretary of the South African Communist Party (SACP), and one of the country's most popular politicians. 

At the age of 15, Hani joined the ANC Youth League and was active in protests against the Bantu Education Act. After his graduation, he joined the ANC's armed wing, MK, and would become its chief of staff. Hunted by the apartheid regime, he was forced into hiding and changed his name to Chris.

He received military training in the Soviet Union and fought in the joint operations between MK and Zimbabwe People's Revolutionary Army during Zimbabwe's war of liberation. 

When the ANC was unbanned in 1991, Hani returned to South Africa and replaced Joe Slovo as the leader of the SACP.

On  April 10, 1993 Hani was gunned down by white supremacist Janusz Waluś in the driveway of his home.

Happy birthday to the Palestinian resistance icon and former guerrilla fighter, Leila Khaled! She went down in history for her fearless operations and is still active for the Palestinian cause today.
 
Her family had to flee Israeli ethnic cleansing from their hometown Haifa when Khaled was only a small child, ending up as refugees in Lebanon. Khaled and her family later joined the Marxist-Leninist Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine (PFLP), which schooled her in the Guerrilla struggle in the hinterland of the Jordanian capital Amman.
 
Khaled and the PFLP gained attention in 1969 for hijacking a passenger plane without bloodshed, based on the suspicion that the former Israeli ambassador to the U.S. was onboard. The photo of Khaled wearing the kuffiyeh and carrying an AK-47 rifle, being the first woman ever to hijack a plane, spread across the globe.

Despite that 1 million properties lie empty, the number of people living on the streets is increasing year-on-year. For Anastasios, music has been his only escape, a way to find solace from the abusive home he was forced to flee and his struggle with Glioma.

Palestinian resistance icon, Leila Khaled, spoke to red. media and shared her thoughts on why an Intifada has already begun inside occupied Palestine. "This is now an Intifada, but in a different way" – says the former Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine militant. 

Khaled argues that throughout world history, armed struggle has been the only way for oppressed people to fight back, such as in Vietnam and Apartheid South Africa. She says the recent resistance in occupied Palestine is part of a new armed approach against Israeli rule.

Israeli military jets launched air raids in the Gaza Strip, the most densely populated area in the world, and bombed an area close to the city of Tyre in, southern Lebanon. Palestinian Resistance groups in Gaza responded by firing a surface-to-air missile at the Israeli aircraft according to Palestinian media agencies. 

The incidents escalated in the wake of the Israeli attack on worshipers in Al-Aqsa Mosque last Wednesday. Lt Col Avichay Adraee, spokesman for the Israeli army, blamed Hamas in Lebanon for the rocket attacks. 

The Lebanese Foreign Ministry announced that Lebanon will file a complaint with the UN Security Council. They added that the Israeli attacks threatened their stability, violated Lebanon's sovereignty, and violated Resolution 1701- UN resolution adopted during the 2006 Lebanon War. 

Two Israeli settlers were shot dead and a third was injured in the Jordan Valley region, in the northeast of the occupied West Bank. The shooting was in response to the Israeli attacks on the Gaza Strip.

Clashes have broken out again between protesters and police on the 11th national day of action, including strikes and protests in France against President Emmanuel Macron's plan to raise the retirement age from 62 to 64.
