100 Lebanese rockets were fired from southern Lebanon toward Israel in only 15 minutes, according to Israeli media reports. However, Lebanese security sources downplayed the impact of the launches. 

Israel's Channel 12 accused Hezbollah, Hamas, and Jihad of coordinating the attack. 

In response, Israel hit southern Lebanon with artillery fire,according to Reuters .

Israel intercepted at least one rocket using the Iron Dome air defense system. Three people had minor injuries; one was hurt running towards a bomb shelter,Magen David Adom from Israel's emergency services said. 

The attacks came after Israeli Defence Forces (IDF) stormed into Al-Aqsa mosque and attacked worshippers. 

Earlier today, Hezbollah said it would support "all measures" while Palestinian groups may take against Israel after the assault on Al-Aqsa. 

Cross-border rocket attacks between Lebanon and Israel have been rare since the 2006 Israel- Hezbollah war.

Israeli Defence Forces (IDF) stormed Al-Aqsa Mosque in occupied Jerusalem for the second night in a row and assaulted worshipers. 

IDF fired rubber-coated bullets, tear gas, and stun grenades and chased worshipers while beating them with batons. Several injuries were reported by local media.

Worshipers say the IDF forcibly emptied the Al-Aqsa courtyard to pave the way for settlers to break into the mosque. 

Earlier today, dozens of settlers stormed Al-Aqsa under the protection of the IDF to mark the Jewish holiday of Passover.

The raids sparked tensions outside Jerusalem. Several protests were held by Palestinians in Haifa, Umm al-Fahm, and the West Bank.

Watch IDF soldiers pushing Palestinian worshipers as they perform the Duha prayer in Al-Aqsa mosque in occupied Jerusalem. This followed an Israeli raid on the mosque during the holy month of Ramadan.

Finland has officially joined NATO, becoming the 31st member as the military alliance celebrates it's 74th birthday. Overnight, NATO's border with Russia has doubled and with the possibility of the once neutral Finland now hosting U.S nuclear weapons, tensions with Moscow are higher than ever.

Despite the U.S. promise to then Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev at the end of the Cold War that NATO would not expand eastwards, NATO has continued edging closer to Russia's borders. 

NATO was established explicitly as an anti-communist alliance in 1949, supposedly to counter the threat from the Soviet Union. Early on, Chief of General Staff of the German army in Nazi Germany, Adolf Heusinger, was appointed as chair of NATO's military committee.

Known as the North Atlantic Terrorist Organization to its critics, NATO has taken on a much more aggressive imperialist role since the end of the Cold War intervening in Afghanistan, then Yugoslavia and Libya.

Last night Israeli forces violently stormed Al-Qibli mosque in the Al-Aqsa compound in occupied Jerusalem. The IDF soldiers threw stun grenades inside the mosque, cut off the electricity supply, and smashed the door of the mosque's medical clinic.
 
The troops also assaulted women and men as they were reciting and praying during the holy month of Ramadan. Multiple videos show Israeli police dragging women and arresting men while beating them. 
 
The Palestinian Red Crescent said that dozens of worshipers were injured during the raid, and medical staff were prevented from entering the mosque to treat the injured.

Wadi Hilweh Information Center reports  that up to 500 Palestinians were detained, including three paramedics.
 
Early today, settlers also stormed the mosque, guarded by the IDF while Palestinians have been prevented from entering.

Meanwhile, Israel launched a series of air strikes on the besieged Gaya strip, including the south of Gaza City and the Nuseirat refugee camp.

Angry bus drivers attacked Security Minister Sergio Berni in the Argentine capital of Buenos Aires, protesting about the recent killing of one of their colleagues. 65-year-old bus driver Daniel Barrientos was shot dead early on Monday by two people attempting to board his bus to rob passengers. 

Sergio Berni tried to end their strikes by assuring the drivers that investigations and prosecutions were underway. However, the furious bus drivers pelted the minister with stones, beating and thrashing him after he approached them. The ongoing strikes about unsafe working conditions have impacted 14 million people in western Buenos Aires.

Berni was seen bleeding from his face and was forced to wear a cycle helmet as the attacks continued. Berni later told reporters that he sustained a fractured jawbone and undergone concussion therapy during the incident that was live-streamed on local television for 30 minutes.

On Trans Visibility Day we honor Marsha P. Johnson, the trailblazing trans woman whose activism paved the way for greater visibility and acceptance of LGBTQ+ people. 

Johnson was a central figure in the Stonewall uprising of 1969, which marked a turning point in the gay rights movement. Her legacy lives on, and she continues to activists from marginalized communities to this day. Watch now to learn more.

Happy birthday to Alexandra Kollontai - Marxist theorist, politician, diplomat, and the first female minister in history! Kollontai’s influence was highly significant within the Bolshevik party, where she served as the People’s Commissar for Welfare in the first Soviet Government headed by Vladimir Lenin from 1917 to 1918.
 
Kollontai was a fierce advocate for women’s liberation rooted in dialectic materialism, a belief that continues to outstrip many of the ideas put forward by bourgeois feminism. Following the Bolshevik Revolution, Kollontai fought tirelessly for radical new liberties for women, which bore fruit when the Soviet Union became the first country to legalize abortion.
 
Kollontai believed that true women’s liberation could only be achieved through overthrowing capitalism and establishing a socialist society. She also argued that women’s liberation should not be limited to legal and political rights but should include economic, social, and sexual emancipation.

On this day 33 years ago riots engulfed the UK after Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher introduced a "poll tax" which forced everyone to pay a flat tax for local services irrespective of income. 

It was a declaration of war by Thatcher on the working class and would eventually contribute to her downfall. Read more to find out what happened.

Ongoing protests in Kenya about rising inflation have been met with heavy police repression with police firing tear gas at protesters in Nairobi. 

Protests have hit several parts of the country, with one protester shot dead by police earlier this week in the city of Kisumu, near the Ugandan border. The fatality brought the death-toll to two after another protester was killed during protests at Maseno University, also in Kisumu county.

Last year, Ruto accepted another IMF loan of almost $450 million. In order to qualify for the loan, Ruto was obliged to slash public spending and ended subsidies for essentials like fuel and maize, just as the global prices for these commodities were soaring. Ruto is in further talks with the World Bank to secure a $1 billion loan from the U.S. controlled institution. Kenya is drowning in public debt, estimated to stand at nearly $70 billion, equivalent to 62.3 per cent of GDP. Debt repayments take up a staggering 48 per cent of Kenya's revenues.

Thousands of protesters in Ecuador took to the streets of the capital, Quito, demanding the government improve access to water for Indigenous people and the impeachment of President Guillermo Lasso. After marching through the streets, protesters gathered in front of the National Assembly and chanted "Water, yes! Gold, no!" and "Lasso out." 

Critics of the Ecuadorian government condemn unregulated mining for causing environmental destruction and devastating health impacts amongst the Indigenous population.

Although Ecuador has a system of protected areas aiming to help biodiversity and ecosystems, rivers traditionally haven't been included meaning that the local water supplies can include toxic waste. 

On Wednesday Ecuador's constitutional court ruled that the opposition dominated National Assembly can consider the question of whether to impeach Lasso following a 6-3 vote. Lasso faces allegations of crimes against state security and corruption.

As Women's History Month comes to an end and Israeli military escalation continues, watch this rare interview with former communist guerrilla fighter and an icon of the Palestinian resistance, Leila Khaled.

Khaled and the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine (PFLP) gained worldwide attention in 1969 for hijacking a passenger plane without bloodshed, in which they suspected the former Israeli ambassador to the U.S. was onboard.

Khaled, who continues to be politically active, went down in history as the first woman to ever hijack an airplane, becoming the face of the Palestinian struggle for freedom.

Water tanks on roof tops are a common sight across occupied Palestine, not in Israeli settlements which have an unlimited water supply. Watch Faten Elwan in Ramallah break down how Palestinians suffer severe water shortages thanks to Israel's apartheid practises.

Protests against French President Emmanuel Macron's anti-democratic pension reform were brutally attacked by police during the 10th day of national action against the bill. Unions report that 2 million people took part, with the CGT union putting the turnout at 450,000 in Paris alone. 

In Paris, police fired tear-gas and charged at protesters as their march approached the iconic Place de la Nation. In the cities of Nantes, Lille and Toulouse police also attempted to repress massive demonstrations with tear gas and water cannons.

Police say they made 27 arrests in Paris while activist journalists said that several protesters have been badly injured due to police violence in demonstrations that have been taking place non-stop since the weekend.

Clashes have again broken out between French protesters and police amidst the 10th day of national strike and protest against President Emmauel Macron's pension reforms. 

Tensions are high as anger mounts over excessive police violence which shows no sign of tempering. Ahead of today's protest Interior Minister Gerald Darmanin said 13,000 members of the security forces were being deployed, including 5,500 in Paris alone.

More than 30 lawyers wrote an open letter to French newspaper Le Monde on Monday expressing their "great concern" about the arbitrary arrests of hundreds of people, accusing the police of using the threat of arrest as a tactic to deter people protesting. In response, the head of the Paris police claimed all arrests had been justified while Darmanin said many police officers had been injured during the protests. However, there have been calls for an independent investigation into allegations of police brutality. During last Thursday's national strike alone, police made 457 arrests.

Clashes have broken out between police and protesters in the French city of Lyon as thousands of people expressed their outrage over President Emmanuel Macron's pension bill, which raises the retirement age from 62 to 64 and was forced through without a vote.

Hundreds of thousands of French workers are coming out for the 10th national day of strikes and protest this year, as the resistance to President Emmanuel Macron's hated pension bill shows no sign of abating. 

More young people are expected to join the protests compared to last week as anger mounts over excessive police violence witnessed at previous days of national strike. At the same time, around 200 schools have been blockaded by students, according to high school unions.

In between the national strike days, rolling-strikes by workers have ground large parts of France to a halt. On Monday, the Louvre in Paris was forced to close as workers walked out. Meanwhile, almost 16 per cent of fuel stations are suffering from fuel shortages as strikes continue at refineries, including at the country's largest, the TotalEnergies' Gonfreville-l'Orcher plant.  Half of Paris is drowning under 8,000 tons of rubbish due to ongoing refuse workers' strikes.

Almost 80% of the French public oppose President Emmanuel Macron's pension reforms. Despite millions protesting in the streets, he continues to insist it's "necessary" to make France's pension system financially sustainable. Meanwhile, he's given himself a pay rise.  

In 2023:

– Macron's salary has increased by €500 to €15,737 per month, a raise which he justifies because of "inflation".

– The budget of the Élysée Palace (Macron's residence), has increased by €5.2 million to €114.5 million.

– Macron's travel budget has also increased by €1 million to a whopping €16 million.

– The president's staff costs are up €2.8 million to €73.9 million.

Israeli attacks on Palestinians are continuing amid the ongoing protests against Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu. Racist attacks have been occurring more frequently during the Islamic holy month of Ramadan, a period that has seen increased Israeli aggression in recent years.
 
Video footage has shown Israelis attacking people carrying the Palestinian flag at protests and entering occupied East Jerusalem to chase Palestinians and attack ambulances. The "death to the Arabs" chant, popular with far-right Israelis, has also been heard at protests against Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.
 
Israelis have been protesting for months over planned judicial reforms by Netanyahu's extreme-right government that would give it control over the Supreme Court. Under increasing pressure, Netanyahu announced Monday that he would postpone the judicial reforms by a month and offered dialogue with critics.

Ongoing anti-government protests against raging inflation are rocking Kenya and have met heavy police repression. Already one person has been killed and several hundred arrested.

Violent clashes have erupted between protesters and police, with the latter deploying water cannons, tear gas and in some cases lethal gunfire. The protests are organized by opposition leader, Raila Odinga.

The Communist Party of Kenya (CPK) backs the protests against "high cost of living, devaluation of the currency, inflation and chronic unemployment". But the CPK warns Odinga is being "opportunistic," saying his party only wants "negotiation to be part of the corrupt government."

NASA recorded the longest and most severe drought since records began in the Horn of Africa region a few months ago, threatening millions with starvation. Kenya's crippling inflation has been hovering at above 9% for months, hitting the highest numbers since 2017.

Thousands of Spanish medical workers took to the streets of Madrid to rally against privatization and cuts in the health care sector. Medical workers' unions are campaigning for 7,000 to 8,000 new workers to be recruited in order to ease the workload of doctors and nurses.

Last month 250,00 protesters including medical workers held a similar rally in the capital. Critics of Madrid's regional chief, Isabel Díaz Ayuso, say her administration spends less on health care than any other Spanish region even though it has the highest per capita income. They report that for every two euros that is spent on health care in Madrid one euro goes to the private sector causing long waiting lists and overworked health care professionals.

15 years ago today, Manuel Marulanda, the "founding father" of Colombia's FARC-EP,  died. Under his command, FARC had 20k fighters & controlled 40% of the country.

Marulanda's revolutionary character was forged during his impoverished upbringing to a peasant family in rural Colombia. He was 18 when the 10-year armed conflict erupted following the assassination of the socialist presidential candidate Jorge Eliécer Gaitán in the 1950s. Marulanda co-founded the FARC-EP in 1964, aiming to overthrow the Colombian state and build a socialist society.
 
FARC's founding launched a 50-year power struggle facing brutal counter-insurgency tactics, right-wing paramilitaries, drug traffickers, and U.S. imperialism. In this period, Marulanda rose to become an internationally respected revolutionary leader and Colombia's most wanted man.
 
Marulanda died from heart failure in a remote guerrilla camp aged 77. The International Day of the Right to Rebellion coincides with his death anniversary, commemorating his legacy.

Lebanese protesters attempted to storm government buildings in Beirut on Wednesday as police fired tear gas at them. The protesters, mainly retired soldiers, were angry about their low pensions and the catastrophic economic situation in the country, as Lebanon grapples with its worst ever economic crisis.

It is the latest expression of public anger a week after the Lebanese pound hit an all time low of 100,000 to the U.S dollar. In February furious crowds burned several banks in Beirut following the devaluation of the pound. Protesters also regularly block roads while last month even police raided a bank in south Lebanon demanding payment of their salaries.

Although the decline of hard currency has been a key factor U.S sanctions have devastated the Lebanese economy. Sanctions largely focused on the anti-Zionist political party Hezbollah, whose bloc has 62 seats in the Lebanese parliament, as well as crippling sanctions on neighboring Syria, have effectively placed Lebanon under an economic blockade.

Another nationwide day of strikes and protests, involving hundreds of thousands of people are taking place across France on Thursday as the population continues resisting President Emmauel Macron's bill to increase the retirement age from 62 to 64.

Trade unions have predicted that Thurday's ninth national day of action against the bill will draw huge crowds and rolling strikes by workers, including garbage collectors will continue. In recent days huge piles of trash have built up in Paris while oil deliveries into France have also been disrupted. Teachers will also walk out while train travel and airports will be severely impacted. 

Polls have consistently shown that around 70% of the French public oppose Macron's plans with protests against the reforms beginning in mid January. However protests have grown following Macron's decision to force the bill through the National Assembly without a vote last Friday.

Thursday marks the first day of the Muslim holy month of Ramadan, a period that has in recent years seen increased aggression by Israeli troops against Palestinians. This has included raids on the Al-Aqsa Mosque and air strikes targeting Gaza.

Happy birthday revolutionary socialist, "guerrilla intellectual" and pan-African activist Walter Rodney!

In his landmark book “How Europe Underdeveloped Africa”, Rodney explained how European “development” was the flip-side of African “underdevelopment”. He methodically proved how centuries of European colonial exploitation have exhausted Africa of its wealth while enriching the West. 

Born into a working-class family in what was then British Guyana, in the 1960s Rodney taught at Jamaica's University of the West Indies while also holding public lectures on the streets known as “groundings”. There crowds gathered to discuss radical political ideas and these sessions played a key role in the development of revolutionary thinking in the Caribbean.

In 1968, Rodney was banned from Jamaica forcing him to return to his home country, Guyana. In 1980 he was assassinated by a car bomb, an attack widely believed to have been a political assassination orchestrated by the state.

Clashes erupted again on Tuesday across France as protesters furious at President Emmanuel Macron’s attempt to raise the retirement age from 62 to 64 clashed with police. In Paris protesters took to the streets to vent their fury a day after the French government survived two no confidence votes. 

Protests against the reform have been going on since mid-January but tensions were inflamed on Friday when Macron asked Prime Minister Elisabeth Borne to force the reform through the National Assembly without a vote. 

Despite that polls show 70% of the French population is opposed to the reforms, Macron has refused to back-down. He has ruled out withdrawing the reform holding a referendum or dissolving the National Assembly.

Unions have been at the forefront of the protests with garbage collectors and refinery workers particularly prominent. As a result, trash has built up on the streets in Paris and oil deliveries into France have been disrupted. A day of strikes and protests has been called for Thursday.

On this day in 1931, Indian socialist revolutionary Bhagat Singh and his comrades, Sukhdev Thapar and Shivaram Rajguru, were executed by India's British colonial rulers.

The three were in their early '20s when they were executed and in his short life, Singh became one of the most influential revolutionaries in India's independence movement.

In 1928, Singh, Thapar and Rajguru killed British colonial police officer, James Saunders in Lahore, to avenge the murder of independence leader Lala Lajpat Rai at the hands of British colonial police. Singh mistook Saunders for Police Superintendent James Scott, who he had intended to assassinate. Scott had ordered the police baton charge on Rai that eventually ended in his death.

On March 23, 1931, Bhagat Singh and his two fellow revolutionaries were hanged. As they marched towards the gallows, they reportedly chanted "Down with British Imperialism" and "Down with capitalism!".

French workers continue to rebel against President Emmanuel Macron’s attempt to force through his pension bill raising the retirement age from 62 to 64. Macron ordered Prime Minister Elisabeth Borne to force the amendment through the National Assembly without a vote.

Since Friday, clashes have been raging across France between protesters and police. While Macron appeared defiantly on TV last night, on the capital's streets police used tear gas against protesters who set garbage cans of fire to repel them. 

A national day of strikes and protests has been declared for Thursday as unions demand the withdrawal of the pension reform bill. 

In the National Assembly opposition politicians sang the national anthem and held up banners indicating their opposition to the retirement age being set at 64 as a special constitutional power known as article 49.3 was used to force the law through. Polls have consistently shown that most French citizens are against the changes.

For Women’s History Month, watch Lady Izdihar discuss the phrase of Russian revolutionary, Vladimir Lenin, “every kitchen maid must learn to run the state”. With this call, Lenin urged women to join their local Soviet worker’s council and become an important part of the revolution. 

Just a few months after seizing power in 1917, the Bolsheviks issued a new family code which separated marriage from the church, allowed marrying women to choose a surname and provided extended grounds for women to divorce. In 1920, the Soviet Union became the first country to legalize abortion, and then the first country to criminalize marital rape in 1922.

Labor laws were also reformed to help women enter the workplace on an equal basis to men. For example, they were given equal rights in terms of insurance in case of illness from work and eight weeks of paid maternity leave. Men and women were also granted a minimum wage and paid holiday leave.

On this day in 1947, U.S. Cold War paranoia reached its pinnacle when President Harry Truman signed Executive Order 9835 to tackle alleged communist infiltration.

Also known as the "loyalty order" it paved the way for 3 million government employees to come under investigation, and was the prelude to the anti-communist witch hunts known as McCarthyism led by Republican Senator Joseph McCarthy.

The order enabled the FBI to research the associations and beliefs of federal employees and if “derogatory information” was found they could launch investigations using confidential witnesses. Employees could be fired if “reasonable doubts” existed about their loyalty to the U.S. There was no right of appeal against the decision made by loyalty boards.

300 government employees were dismissed for allegedly being a security risk while 5,000 offered voluntary resignations following investigations with many taking place during humiliating public congressional hearings. No espionage charges were launched.

For St. Patrick's Day ☘️, we remember the Argentinian revolutionary in whose veins "flowed the blood of Irish rebels".

For St. Patrick's Day, we honor the leader of Ireland's revolutionary socialist struggle, James Connolly.

Connolly founded the Irish Socialist Republican Party in 1898 and in 1903 the Irish Transport & General Workers' Union, which became the largest union in Ireland and led the 1913 Dublin Lockout. 

Connolly also played a leading role in the Easter Rising of 1916 against Britain, waged at the height of WWI under the slogan: "England's misfortune is Ireland's opportunity". On May 12, Connolly and other leaders of the rising were tried by a secret British court-martial that lasted only a few minutes and executed by firing squad. 

Connolly believed sacrificing his life was necessary to inspire Irish people to take up arms against British rule, which indeed it would come to do in the years and decades that followed. Shortly before his execution his wife Lille said to him: "Your life, James, your beautiful life." to which he replied: "Well, Lillie, hasn't it been a beautiful life, and isn't this a good end?
Today, millions of people around the world celebrate Irish St. Patrick's Day, a festival from the tiny island of Ireland. ☘️ Do you know why? Read on 👉

Thousands of workers across Greece have joined a 24-hour strike in protest of the country's austerity measures and privatization policies following a fatal train crash in Tempi that claimed the lives of 57 people. The tragedy has led to weeks of protests in the country.

According to police reports, over 25,000 demonstrators flooded the streets of Athens. Video footage of the strike shows intense clashes between the riot police and protesters, who were seen hurling Molotov cocktails.

The All-Workers Militant Front (PAME), the union federation that organized the strike, has accused the right-wing government of Greece of prioritizing profits over human lives. "You count profits and losses - We count human lives!" PAME said in a statement, calling for an end to austerity and privatization, which they hold responsible for the crash.

Outrage burst through the streets of Paris following the announcement that President Emmanuel Macron will force through his wildly unpopular pension reforms without a vote in France’s National Assembly.

Macron is triggering article 49.3 of the French constitution which permits the government to declare a bill “adopted” without a vote in the National Assembly - the lower house of the French Parliament.

Head of the French Communist Party, Fabien Roussel, said: “This government is not worthy of our Fifth Republic, of French democracy. Until the very end, parliament has been ridiculed, humiliated.” 

Macron’s government initially claimed the reforms, which will raise the retirement age and force people to work more consecutive years, were designed to make the system “fairer”. It has more recently admitted that the true goal was “savings”. Macron, a former investment banker, last year awarded himself a pay rise, bringing his monthly salary to 15,737 euros citing "inflationary pressures"

Today we remember the worst single poison gas attack against civilians in history, the Halabja massacre ordered by Saddam Hussein in 1988 against the Kurdish city during the Iran-Iraq war. 

The UN classified the massacre as genocide. Over 7,000 people were killed, most of them civilians. The massacre was part of a major counterinsurgency campaign against oppressed Kurds who joined the Iranians in the fight against Hussein.

The massacre was made possible by direct and indirect support from the U.S. and Germany, which manufactured and supplied the poison gas. The Halabja massacre left many victims suffering the long term effects, including cancer, skin diseases, infertility, and congenital deformities.

Burkinabe revolutionary, Thomas Sankara compares imperialism to a "bad student...which never learns the lessons of its failures." 

Thomas Sankara was a communist revolutionary leader who became President of Burkina Faso in 1983. His revolutionary ideology drew inspiration from Marxism-Leninism, pan-Africanism, women's liberation and anti-imperialism. Sankara was assassinated in 1987 in a coup that several critics have alleged was backed by France. 

France colonized Burkina Faso until 1960 and upon coming to power Sankara's government took several steps to reduce France's ongoing neocolonial control of the country. One of Sankara's first moves was to rename the country from Upper Volta to Burkina Faso, meaning "land of the upright people".

What does apartheid look like in practice? Look no further than Israeli-occupied Palestine. 

In 2002, Israel built the "Separation Wall" which slices through Palestinian communities, neighborhoods and agricultural land. Often referred to as the "Apartheid Wall", the United Nations has long branded it "illegal". Unlike the US-Mexico border wall or the India-Bangladesh border fence, the Separation Wall cuts through areas within a country.

Video footage shows an Israeli checkpoint through the wall in the occupied West Bank village of Hablah. Palestinians must pass through this checkpoint to reach their daily destinations. Complicated and constantly changing regulations, permits and militarization of checkpoints are part of Israel's "bureaucratic maze" policy, a crucial feature in the relentless repression of Palestinians.

The human rights organization Machsom Watch writes "Israel’s policy of denying Palestinians their right to enter territories has become an instrument of controlling an entire population."

Happy birthday Albert Einstein! One of the most intelligent people in the world and, what is lesser known, a socialist!

Einstein's most well-known work on socialism is his text "Why Socialism?" published in 1949. Einstein argued that capitalism, focusing on profit and competition, led to economic inequality, exploitation and conflicts between social classes.

At the height of U.S. anti-communist paranoia, the U.S. government suspected Einstein of being a communist spy, and former FBI director J. Edgar Hoover called him "an extreme radical". By the time of Einstein's death in 1955, the FBI had collected over 1,400 documents on his activities.

Einstein fled Nazi Germany to the U.S. in 1933. Although he was subjected to intense surveillance and lived trough McCarthyism, he never backed down from his commitment to his revolutionary principles.
